label: Petition from Alexander McDonald to the St. Andrew's Society
description: Petition of Alexander McDonald to the St. Andrew's Society requesting assistance, explaining that he cannot support himself because his profession as a merchant was unsuccessful.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Petition of Alexander McDonald to the St. Andrew's Society requesting assistance, explaining that he cannot support himself because his profession as a merchant was unsuccessful.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
1769 [written in top-left margin of paper in pencil at later date]

To the Worthy Gentlemen of St. Andrews Club Assembled.

The Humble Petition of Alexander McDonald

Sheweth

That your Petitioner is a poor man a Native of Scotland, late Merchant at Winchester in Virginia, having met with many losses and Disappointments in Trade, most Humbly presumes to present this his Petition to the worthy society now assembled in honour of our Tutelar Saint. He also hopes that the said Gentlemen will not suppose that he is brought to this Exigency through Miscondut or any other ill behavior, but fortune frowned upon him notwithstanding his Assiduity and diligence in his Station of Life: Petitioner is very sorry and almost ashamed to trouble the Worthy Gentlemen with this Petition but hopes they will take his case into Consideration as it's nothing but necessity obliges him thereto, Their Charity shall be ever Acknowledged, and he as in duty bound will ever pray.

Alexander McDonald [signature of applicant]
